H0.text: A footprint in a rock is the best example of a fossil that scientists study to learn about extinct plants and animals.

H1.text: A seashell under water is the best example of a fossil for scientists who study fossils to learn about extinct plants and animals.

H2.text: A leaf in a mudpuddle is the best example of a fossil for scientists studying extinct plants and animals.

H3.text: A bone on top of a sand pile is the best example of a fossil that scientists study to learn about extinct plants and animals.

A4.text: Fossil footprints made by tetrapod vertebrates are difficult to identify to a particular species of animal, but they can provide valuable information such as the speed, weight, and behavior of the organism that made them.

A5.text: Trace fossils provide us with indirect evidence of life in the past, such as the footprints, tracks, burrows, borings, and feces left behind by animals, rather than the preserved remains of the body of the actual animal itself.

A6.text: An international team's discovery of a set of 1.5 million-year-old human ancestor footprints in Ileret, Kenya provides the earliest direct evidence of a modern human style of upright walking.

A7.text: Footprints have been preserved as fossils and provide evidence of prehistoric life.
